title: Is a majority shareholder vote required for a corporate chapter 7 bk?
question: 2 out of the 3 shareholders, holding 33.3% per person want to file. Can it still go forward even if the lone holdout does not want the bk?
answers: Most of the time a corporate bankruptcy is like raping the company. The assets get sold at fire sale prices & no discharge means the remaining debts still exist. Anyone who guaranteed the debts probably will end up in Chapter 7 as well. shareholders should be educated before voting 'cause they are jumping off a cliff. Hope this perspective helps.
This would depend on what your bylaws, shareholders agreement, and other governing documents say.

The definitive answer is in your bylaws, but without more, a majority of the directors elected by a majority of the shareholders can decide to move forward over the objection of a minority director and shareholder.
